Award.AwardTitle: Atomization of Liquids in Non-isothermal Environments: Multi-scale Modeling and Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Atomization of liquids is a key component in many natural phenomena and technical processes. Yet, detailed understanding of the fundamental physical processes is incomplete, due to the inherent complexity of atomization and the inability to experimentally observe the processes in detail. This project focuses on improved understanding of the phenomenon by computational studies, on massively parallel computational facilities, of mathematical models that incorporate the interaction and competition among several forces acting on multiple length and time scales. High-fidelity gas/liquid interface tracking algorithms based on the level-set approach will be combined with efficient Lagrangian descriptions of small-scale liquid droplets. Thermal Marangoni effects due to the temperature dependence of surface tension will be included, along with evaporation and related effects of latent heat, with the intent to examine the extent to which these processes affect the fragmentation cascades of droplets in high-inertia flow.


The project will enable breakthroughs in the understanding of physical mechanisms that govern the process of atomization, with potential impact on a broad range of applications. Foremost among these are energy systems, where the design of fuel-efficient and low-polluting engines hinges on the air/fuel mix for optimal combustion, and that in turn depends critically on the droplet size distribution from the atomization of the injected jet of fuel. This will aid in achieving national goals of energy independence and environment sustainability. Other applications include aerosol drug delivery, agricultural sprays, and fire-fighting (here atomization of the water jet is to be avoided for increased flame quenching). Accurate atomization models of waves producing sea spray and small air bubbles driven deep into the ocean by breaking waves, especially those associated with large-scale storms and hurricanes, can lead to improved weather and climate modeling and predictions of the impact of greenhouse gases on global warming. The project also includes the interdisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atomization of liquids is a key component in many natural phenomena
and technical processes. And yet, detailed understanding of the
fundamental physical processes is incomplete. This is in part due to
the inherent complexity of atomization, as well as the inability to
experimentally observe the processes in detail. Breakthroughs in our
understanding of atomization become possible through advances in the
mathematical modeling of the physics and the computational techniques
to solve the governing equations that incorporate the interaction and
competition between several forces acting on multiple length and time
scales, combined with the use of massively parallel computational
facilities. To bridge the gap between experiments that cannot acquire
detailed, time-dependent and three-dimensional measurements and
simplified computational approaches that need vast amounts of
empirical input, we have developed high-fidelity gas/liquid interface
tracking algorithms based on the level-set approach combined with
efficient Lagrangian descriptions of the resulting small-scale liquid
droplets.  We have also included thermal Marangoni effects due to the
temperature dependence of the surface tension and surface tension
effects due to large localized deformations of the interface, and
investigated how these processes affect the fragmentation cascades of
droplets in high-inertia flow.

The predictive models and accurate and robust numerical techniques
resulting from this project can be expected to have a long-term
profound impact on a range of disciplines, such as in energy systems,
where the design of fuel-efficient and low-polluting engines hinges on
the air/fuel mix for optimal combustion, and this depends critically
on the droplet size distribution from the atomization of the injected
jet of fuel. This will aid in achieving national goals of energy
independence and environment sustainability. Other applications
include aerosol drug delivery, agricultural sprays and oil plume
break-up.

The project has also been instrumental in the interdisciplinary
training of graduate and undergraduate students. One student completed
his PhD during this project and is now a post-doctoral fellow at
Cornell University, and the two undergraduate researches supported by
the project are currently in PhD programs, one in mathematics at the
University of Colorado Boulder and the other in scientific computation
at the University of Maryland.
